titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Charles George Foster papers, 1879-1972
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, May 2019

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Journal (15 p.), photograph, and biographical information about Foster's brother, Richard Witty Foster, a politician and government official in South Australia. The typescript journal (Aug. 1-Nov. 1, 1879) describes a voyage from England to New Zealand by Charles Foster as a young man seeking agricultural employment at his destination. After sightseeing in London, he boarded the steamship AFGHAN, taking a route to Plymouth, St. Vincent, Cape Town, the Kangaroo Islands, Melbourne and Hobart in Australia, and on to New Zealand. Foster took a train to Adelaide, South Australia, in an unsuccessful attempt to visit his brother. One entry mentions the end of the Zulu War, the Zulu king as prisoner, and returning regiments. The photograph is of Charles Foster and his second wife Margaret in the early 1930s.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Charles George Foster Papers, 1879-1972, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, May 2019.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Journal (15 p.), photograph, and biographical information about Foster's brother, Richard Witty Foster, a politician and government official in South Australia. The typescript journal (Aug. 1-Nov. 1, 1879) describes a voyage from England to New Zealand by Charles Foster as a young man seeking agricultural employment at his destination. After sightseeing in London, he boarded the steamship AFGHAN, taking a route to Plymouth, St. Vincent, Cape Town, the Kangaroo Islands, Melbourne and Hobart in Australia, and on to New Zealand. Foster took a train to Adelaide, South Australia, in an unsuccessful attempt to visit his brother. One entry mentions the end of the Zulu War, the Zulu king as prisoner, and returning regiments. The photograph is of Charles Foster and his second wife Margaret in the early 1930s.
